text:
:champagne: _You have opened a new, empty shared channel._ 
_Share <https://www.smooz.io/room/5de8d3468265f1000454fcf8|this link> with other teams to invite them in it_
<@U4VR52RQE> has renamed the channel from "z-shared-25" to "steve-and-matilde"
name: steve-and-matilde

text:
Hey Matilde, please meet Steve your incredible E-Mentor we've been telling you about :smile:.  Feel free to introduce yourselves, say a little bit about what you would like to get out of the mentorship and continue chatting within this channel. :wave:

I will now be leaving the channel, but please direct message myself or penny-prospela if you have any questions. All the best for now! :slightly_smiling_face:

Hi Matilde. I guess the best way to start if you tell me a bit about yourself, what you're experiences are and what you plan on doing in the future. Hopefully I can give you a few of my own personal experience and some advice on whatever you need. =]

Hi! I'm sorry for the late reply, I was only able to get to my computer now. I'm a first year animation student, and I don't really have any work related experience. I'd like to work in film or tv, but my main goal is to work in games, maybe in character or cinematic animation :smile: It's very nice to meet you and I'm looking forward to talking with you!

Don't worry about the late replies. I'll probably reply late a few times too! We both have other stuff to do as well so it's perfectly fine.
Where are you studying at the moment? Is the course good at teaching animation? (I only ask because my course wasn't very good.)
I have worked in the games industry before up at Frontier in Cambridge. I liked it quite a lot and it was very interesting to see how a game gets made and not just doing the animation. However, a lot of my time was also spent dealing with bug fixes, problem-solving and some coding. I have a feeling that's probably the same for most places. Unless you do cinematics animation I guess.
If you have any questions, please ask away. Ultimately, I'm here to answer any questions you have and give you some advice based on those questions. =]
Oh, someone at work just sent this round and I thought you might be interested in it

attachments.title: Animschool on Instagram: “We are offering a FREE two-week live game animation class: How to Get Started in Game Animation! It will be about 90 minutes each.⁠ ⁠ Come…”
attachments.text: 170 Likes, 2 Comments - Animschool (@animschool) on Instagram: “We are offering a FREE two-week live game animation class: How to Get Started in Game Animation! It…”
attachments.fallback: Instagram: Animschool on Instagram: “We are offering a FREE two-week live game animation class: How to Get Started in Game Animation! It will be about 90 minutes each.⁠ ⁠ Come…”

text:
Ahh I'm glad with late replies! It's true, we're both busy with our own stuff :grin:
I'm studying in UCA Farnham! I'm really happy with the course, and we'll get to learn traditional, CG and stop-motion animation during the course, so that's good. Right now we're mostly learning the basics and developing our drawing skills. I'd say it's a good course for learning animation!
That's something I'd be interested to see as well! I do want to focus more on animation, but I think that learning a bit of coding would be good if I do end up working in games. I also wouldn't mind trying to develop my own short games as well
I guess one of my main questions would be how you see the industry and the demand for animators? Is there a position that tends to get less applications than others, and what do you think would be the best course of action to take when applying for an animation related job? I know I'm still early in my course, but it's best to get an idea of how things work :smile:
And that sounds great! I'll make sure to attend it. Thanks for telling me!
